bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1942

div1.p: Wood is pleased that Hench has found the Lazear materials. She agrees that she should obtain Blossom Reed's written permission in order to examine copies of Walter Reed's letters.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, April 14, 1942
div1.p:
I was interested and pleased to see the clipping you sent
me. I'm glad that you have finally made the announcement
about the notebook - I was afraid somebody, maybe Dr. Mal-
loch, was going to beat you to it. When the letters of
Lazear are ready for exposure to the interested eye I shall
be very keen to see them. Weren't you smart to find
them!

I'm so sorry that all this business about Blossom's letters
is being such a nuisance to you. You're quite right, I
can't help thinking, to want her permission in writing, be-
cause although cordial and as nice as she can be she is al-
so quite scattered, and then only way of being sure
that she quite fully undersatnds what you want is to pin
her down in black and white.

The colored woman who cleans for me here tells me that
she is from Gloucester County, Virginia. We practically had
old home week when I told her I had been there. She didn't
know about Reed, but she knew all about the Belroi plantation
where he was born.

I think I'm going to use lymphadenoma for my disease - not
mine personally, but the one I was wondering about - I fished
it out of Austin Flint's Clinical Practice which came out in
1877.

closer.seg:
P. S. Dr. Cooke can't remember that anybody vomited --
I think that's probably just another of Agramonte's
not too reliable anecdotes
